item.title: Ritu Goel vs Religare Broking Limited on 26 June, 2021
item.description:
2. I have heard Sh. S. S Sobti, Ld. Counsel for petitioner; Sh. Sachin Mittal, Ld. Counsel for respondent and perused the relied upon precedents and records of the case including written arguments of Ld. Counsel for parties as well as arbitral proceedings record and given my thoughtful consideration to the rival contentions put forth.

3. Shorn of unnecessary details, brief facts of the case of petitioner are as under :

A. Petitioner was a client of Respondent since January, 2016 for trading in NSE Equity/Derivative segment. She was regularly investing/trading in market through respondent. Petitioner had authorized her husband Mr. Anand Goel as her authorized representative for trading with respondent.

item.title: Omp (Comm.) No. 211/2019 vs Inam & Co. Engineer & Contractors on 26 June, 2021
item.description:
(iii) Ms. Bela Banerjee, Fa&CAO/Const.(Retd.), Co-Arbitrator. The Arbitral Tribunal awarded sum of Rs. 9,62,000/- to the claimant/present respondent as cost of work done by them as per Claim No. 4 as well as simple interest @ 12% per annum payable by present petitioner to the claimant/respondent in the event of failure of making of payment of award sum within period of 90 days from the date of publishing of the award.

OMP (Comm.) No. 211/2019 Union of India vs Inam & Co. Engineer & Contractors Page 1 of 15

2. Initially petitioner filed appeal under Section 34 of the Act before the Court of Ld. Additional District Judge-I, Ferozepur, Punjab bearing title Divisional Engineer-IV, Northern Railway, Ferozepur vs Inam & Co. Engineer & Contractors, Kaka Road, Nai Sarak, Sri Nagar. Said case was given Arbitration Case no. 31/RBT and was having CIS No. ARB/09/2018 and CNR No. PBFZ010020922018. Said appeal was dismissed by Sh. Gurnam Singh-II, Learned Additional District Judge-I, Ferozepur vide order dated 05/08/2019 holding that said court has no territorial jurisdiction to try and decide the said petition under Section 34 of the Act as such petition challenging the award passed by Arbitrator under the Act is maintainable only at the place, where the award was passed in accordance with the agreed place of arbitration between parties in the agreement; whereas in the said case the award was passed in New Delhi.

item.description:

item.description:

Mr. Desh Raj Thakur, Additional Advocate General, for the respondent through Video Conferencing.

item.title: CRMPM/1171/2021 on 26 June, 2021
item.description:
petitioner.

Mr. Amit Dhumal, Dy. Advocate General, for the respondent-State.

Through Video Conference Notice. Mr. Amit Dhumal, learned Deputy Advocate General, appears and accepts service of notice on behalf of the respondent-State. Status report be filed by the respondent before the next date of hearing.

List on 1 st July, 2021.

Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that the petitioner has been falsely implicated in FIR No. 97/2021, dated 24.6.2021, registered under Sections 323, 452 readwith Section 34 of Indian Penal Code, at Police Station, Theog, District Shimla. Learned counsel further submits that the petitioner has apprehension of his arrest in the aforesaid FIR. In view of the submission so made, it is ordered that till the next date of hearing, in the the event of arrest of the petitioner in the aforesaid FIR, he shall be released on bail on his furnishing personal bond in the sum of `25,000/- with one local surety in the like amount, to the satisfaction of Arresting Officer, subject to following conditions:

item.title: CR.A/54/2017 on 26 June, 2021
item.description:
26.06.2021. Present: Ms. Sheetal Vyas, Advocate, for the applicant/appellant.

.

Mr. Ashok Sharma, Advocate General with Mr. Vikas Rathore, Mr. Vinod Thakur, Mr. Hemanshu Misra, Additional Advocate Generals and Mr. Bhupinder Thakur, Deputy Advocate General, for the respondent.

(Through Video Conferencing) Cr.M.P. No.929 of 2021.

The applicant/appellant has been convicted and sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for ten years and to pay a fine of Rs.1,00,000/- (Rupees One Lac) for the commission of offence under Section 15/29 of the Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act (for short 'ND&PS Act') and in default of payment of fine to further undergo simple imprisonment for two year.

item.title: CS/61/2021 on 26 June, 2021
item.description:
Video Conferencing.

OMP No. 224 of 2021 Notice, returnable on 20.07.2021, the date for which notice in the main suit has already been issued to the non-applicants/defendants. Steps for service be taken during course of the day, if not already taken. Learned counsel for the applicant-plaintiff submits that steps have already been taken.

It is submitted on behalf of the applicant-plaintiff that applicant-plaintiff had entered into a Memorandum Of Understanding (MOU) on 21.07.2017 with non-applicant- defendant No.1 to run Hotel and Restaurant business in future jointly by constructing a Hotel/building on the part of the land comprising in Khasra Nos. 687 and 687/1, situated in Muhal Shuru, Tehsil Manali, District Kullu, H.P. For that purpose, applicant-plaintiff had agreed to sell land measuring 0-08-09 hectare out of total land comprised in Khasra Nos. 687, 687/1, Kita 2, Khatauni No.531/677. In pursuant to MOU applicant- plaintiff had sold 0-08-09 hectare land comprised in Khasra Nos. 687 and 687/1, situated in Muhal Shuru, Tehsil Manali, District Kullu, H.P. in favour of non-applicant-defendant No.1 vide registered sale deed dated 26.07.2017. It is pointed out that as per condition No.3 of MOU, it was agreed between applicant- plaintiff and non-applicant/defendant No.1 that they shall have no right to sell, mortgage, transfer or lease the aforesaid land/Hotel to any person/Company/Firm etc. He has further pointed out that after selling the suit land to non- applicant/defendant No.1, applicant-plaintiff and non- applicant/defendant No.1 had entered into a partnership ::: Downloaded on - 26/06/2021 20:19:00 :::HCHP through a registered Deed of partnership dated 28.07.2017 and in that partnership also, as per term and condition No.5, both .

item.title: CWP/557/2021 on 26 June, 2021
item.description:
26.6.2021 Present: Mr. Gaurav Sharma, Advocate, for the petitioner.

Mr. Sumesh Raj, Additional Advocate General, for the respondent-State.

THROUGH VIDEO-CONFERENCING Learned Additional Advocate General, while placing on record communication dated 22.6.2021 issued under the signatures of the Engineer-in-Chief, Himachal Pradesh Public Works Department, states that the relief claimed in the instant petition stands granted to the petitioner, as such, present petition has been rendered infructuous.

item.description:
26.06.2021 Present: Mr. Kush Sharma, Advocate, for the petitioners.

Mr. Ashok Sharma, Advocate General, Mr. Nand Lal Thakur, Additional Advocate General, and Mr. Rajat Chauhan, Law Officer for respondents No. 1 and 2- State (Through Video Conference) CMP No. 6712 of 2021 The respondents have filed CMP No. 6712 of 2021 to re- recall the interim directions issued by this Court vide order on 4.6.202I.

Mr. Kush Sharma, learned counsel for the petitioners wants to file reply to this application. However, Mr. Ashok Sharma, Learned Advocate General, submits that contempt petition has been filed for non compliance of order dated 4.6.2021, which is listed on 28.6.2021.

Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that co-

accused Anjana Devi has already been released on bail by learned Sessions Judge, Hamirpur, H.P. item.title: CRMPM/838/2021 on 26 June, 2021
item.description:
through Video Conferencing.

Mr. Desh Raj Thakur, Additional Advocate General, for the respondent-State, through Video Conferencing.

Learned counsel for the petitioner has cited case law propounded in judgments of Supreme Court in Rakesh Kumar Paul vs. State of Assam, 2017(15) SCC 67; Bikramjit Singh vs. State of Punjab, (2020) 10 SCC 616; and M. Ravindran vs. Intelligence Officer, Directorate of Revenue Intelligence, (2021) 2 SCC 485, to substantiate his prayer for release of the petitioner on the basis of default bail invoking provisions of Section 167 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (Cr.P.C.) by further stating that till 17.06.2021 no challan was filed in the present case.
